subject: Re: [junit] Javadocing test case and other test classes?
msgSnippet: ... It s not a matter of trust for me.  If I had JavaDoc in my test cases, I d distribute the HTML that the javadoc tool generated. I was clarifying what I
messageBody:
On Jan 5, 2005, at 11:52 AM, Kevin Klinemeier wrote:

>
> On Wed, 5 Jan 2005 11:44:15 -0700, Mike Clark <mike@...>
> wrote:
>>
>>
>> On Jan 5, 2005, at 11:39 AM, Kevin Klinemeier wrote:
>>
>>> In general, what I wanted to say was that while Mike's right that
>>> most
>>> of the time the method name is sufficient, sometimes the case is
>>> enough of a corner that you both need and want a short description of
>>> what the heck is going on. Not shipping any javadoc is turning that
>>> 'sometimes' into 'never'.
>>
>> Isn't it simply saying "never in the form of JavaDoc"? The comment
>> still lives in plain text in the test case file itself.
>
> Well, that's true enough, but why would you want to make these
> comments for yourself, but keep them from the people you're shipping
> the unit tests to? If you trust them with the method names, it seems
> like you'd want to entrust them with the occasional descriptions of
> the situation.

It's not a matter of trust for me. If I had JavaDoc in my test cases,
I'd distribute the HTML that the 'javadoc' tool generated.

I was clarifying what I heard to be a concern that not shipping the
JavaDoc HTML would mean that your comments aren't available to readers.
I may have misinterpreted the statement above. I took "not shipping
JavaDoc" to mean not shipping the HTML the 'javadoc' tool produces.
